title: Apoploe Veritas
body:
*What is art, in the age of AI?*

\-

An artificial intelligence made up its own language to speak with itself. So says social media.

Letâ€™s start from the beginning. DALL-E 2 is an image generation model from OpenAI. You feed it text, it churns out art.

The results are striking. Ask it to produce a painting in the style of Salvator Dali; in just a few moments, it will give you pictures you could reasonably confuse for his works.

![If thatâ€™s more your fancy, ask the AI to give you Salvator Dali back from the future to warn us about the terrible dangers of AI.](https://149695847.v2.pressablecdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Screenshot-2022-04-06-at-9.55.11-PM.png)

### Composability

Mashups are the next great frontier. Anything you imagine in words becomes possible.

Endless combinations, available at blazing speeds: current AIs give you results in less than a minute.

At which point you can build on your previous choices, refine your prompt, mix it with another idea.

Not only the image quality is already impressive. Machine learning models keep improving, as theyâ€™re trained on more data.

To the point weâ€™re not sure where that training leads.

### Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables, With Subtitles

DALL-E 2 is great with pictures. But when you ask it to produce text, it gives you nonsense results.

At least, it looks like nonsense.

Researchers Giannis Daras and Alexandros Dimakis entered the above prompt.

![Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FUGhgf_UUAMVgh1?format=jpg&name=240x240)

We see farmers, one of them talking and one of them holding a couple of cabbage-looking things.

â€œAVCOPINITEGOOS VICOOTESSâ€, the AI proudly titles the picture. While our farmerâ€™s speech bubble is graced with a mysterious â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€.

Our real humans decide to experiment. They input â€œVicootessâ€ as a prompt.

DALL-E returns food with vegetables!

Then the researchers prompt the AI with â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€. Here, the results are interesting: birds, and more birds.

Daras concludes: â€œIt seems that the farmers are talking about birds, messing with their vegetables!â€

### Gatekeepers

The Internet being the Internet, people rushed to tell the researchers they were wrong.

![](https://i.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/newsfeed/000/731/143/3e3.jpg)

â€œA few words donâ€™t make a language!â€

â€œPrompts with these words arenâ€™t perfectly reliable!â€

â€œItâ€™s just random noise!â€

There *is* merit to some of these objections. 

They point out important details, and refine the conversation.

Researchers settled on talking about the **hidden vocabulary** of DALL-E 2, rather than its â€œsecret languageâ€.

Itâ€™s unsurprising to see technical details picked apart. But I am surprised thereâ€™s another conversation missing. 

Nobody looks at the art of this art-making AI as art.

### Wings of Liberty

Machine learning algorithms grow with experimentation and repetition. Software engineers train models. Farming the data to their AI. Harvesting results, and refining parameters.

Two farmers talk. They lament the birds, ruining their crops.

Two software engineers talk. They lament gibberish words, ruining their filters and policy rules.

Man makes rules, only for nature to fight back.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird escaping the dynamic, and in that escape being a â€œpestâ€.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird replicating this dynamic, to remind us there is sense in balance - or purpose in chaos.

![Little Troublemaker](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cKW32US4SmaqYNSnv2FBr.jpg?height=482&width=356)

The AI does not think as such. 

There is no *intent* behind any result the model spits out. Any narrative is just that, narrative. 
  
 But then, that is what art is about. A piece that speaks to the viewer, moving them in an unique way.

Iâ€™ve seen plenty of beautiful AI-generated works in the past few months. Either great aesthetic appeal, or intriguing combinations.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is the first piece I keep coming back to. Itâ€™s the first piece I like as art.

There is a striking imagery there. 

Without getting into tedious politics, itâ€™s undeniable the world is increasingly polarized between haves and havenots. 

Every AI company is filled with haves. They publish their own codes of conduct, laws, regulations, calls for responsibility; in language coated with not-so-subtle assertions of their own cultural values as universal rules.

Havenots are not so happy with this situation. Models get trained on public data, then results are filtered by private committees. 

To be sure, nobody is entitled to the labor of AI researchers. However, there is a feeling of exploitation when incredible creativity tools with the potential to unlock anything you can imagine become locked at the whim of a few masters. 

Whether said masters are benevolent dictators or tyrannical oppressors, nobody wants to be told what to think - and what not to think.

\-

As a sidenote, while the distinction between â€œhavesâ€ and â€œhavenotsâ€ generally reflects capital, itâ€™s not the sole qualifier. 

A 20 years old with nothing but student debt in their name but with great programming skills and ins with AI startups, could be part of the haves. 
  
 A 50 years old with a million dollar networth acquired over decades of menial labor and saving, may be part of the havenots.

Capital is a tool for access. When institutions grow increasingly large, and when skills in demand are increasingly specialized and limited to a handful of individuals, previously respectable capital allows for less access than before.

Less access = less security = less freedom.

\- 

Apoploe vesrreaitais illustrates choice in the digital age.

For every rule, there is a way to bypass that rule. Build a wall as tall as you want. Weâ€™ll craft our own wings and fly over it.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is meaningful particularly because it is, in fact, meaningless. There is no intent. To view a metaphor here is itself a choice. 

In interpretation we have power.

### Choosing Optimism

Perhaps this is all too serious a take. I would take the side of freedom plainly because **it is more fun.**

Itâ€™s fun to wonder about the endless creativity unlocked when you make better tools and give them to everyone.

Itâ€™s fun to build on what others have made and to watch them build on your own derivative.

Itâ€™s fun to grow a pie with as big a collective as you want.

[Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/) has a great approach to this. 

Theyâ€™re a smaller AI company running a paid beta program. Once youâ€™re in, that beta happens on their Discord server. You prompt their bot, and get an image in return.

By default, this happens in public channels. Which means anyone else can see your prompts and results. They can riff on your ideas, directly ask the bot for variations or upscales of your own pictures.

This makes for a tremendous resource. Tied with the Discord search tool, you have this live database of pictures and prompts, guiding you towards what you want. Your own actions inspire and help everyone else.

![Midjourney is great at creepy gothic art](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Q2qHrPMPPokPZUw5yoSpW.png?height=593&width=593)

### Free Enough

To be fair, Midjourney has a code of conduct similar to all the other AI companies. We donâ€™t escape that dynamic here.

I personally donâ€™t mind it.

Yes, despite all that â€œfight the powerâ€ bit earlierâ€¦

I think the way Midjourney does this might be key. Other projects show you scraps of awesome technology. Youâ€™re the Oliver Twist orphan staring at pastries through the window, never able to get in. Midjourney lets you apply, then eventually lets you in.

Once youâ€™re in, youâ€™re with a whole community of people. Sharing ideas in real time.

It may not be realistic to open up the tools to everyone. Especially as the image generation itself is a taxing process for computer hardware, which costs these companies a serious amount of money.

However, there is a right middle point between â€œfully openâ€ and â€œonly available to vetted insidersâ€. 

If AI wants to be diverse, it ought to include a diversity of people. In ideology as well as anything else.

### But Does AI Actually Want Anything?

Letâ€™s ask [DALL-E mini](https://huggingface.co/spaces/dalle-mini/dalle-mini), a fully opensource model accessible by anyone.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/O0DQ9DfyiW8FB8c32jEzg.jpg?height=975&width=866)

I guess the future is blue.

body:
This is the introduction and the first chapter of the book **â€Viveka â€“ the Voice of Inner Guru. â€œ**

The whole book will be tokenized as NFTs on Mirror and, as such, published in 20 articles (20 chapters of the book: The Illusion; India, oh India!; The Accurate description of the Reality; The Crown Jewel; Dead Guru; Living student; Who you?; Leaving the room; The Weakness of the Mind; The Archimedean Point; Three Powers of Maya; Viveka - the Sword of Truth; The Cave of the Mind; Language Can Save Us; Searching for Lakshana; Nine Golden Rules of Viveka; Purification Exercises; What to do with all this?; Dealing with Fear; Ekam Evadvityam: Living without a Center).

Â Â 

**What is *Viveka*?**

> *An evil demon of utmost power and cunning has employed all his energies to deceive me. I shall think that the sky, the air, the earth, colors, shapes, sounds, and all external things are merely the delusions of dreams he has devised to ensnare my judgment. I shall consider myself as not having hands or eyes, or flesh, or blood or senses, but as falsely believing that I have all these things.*

> RenÃ© Descartes 
 Meditations on First Philosophy

Â 

Viveka is a legend, a hidden tool. It is the sharpest scalpel for the most delicate operation of separating an illusion from the true reality. The awkward thing is that each one of us should perform that operation by ourselves. The secret of *how* to do that is not something you have to learn â€“ it's something you'll have to discover. Viveka, a precious jewel capable of delivering you the truth about everything, is not a stranger to your mind. It is a part of it.

Think about it: what if the world you perceive around you is an illusion, a kind of a dream? Something virtual, be it technological, spiritual, or made from some other unknown stuff, but still â€“ not truly real?

And what if someone offers you a means or a tool to pierce through the veils of illusion and see reality as it is? Would you be interested? Would you accept it?

Viveka is such a tool. It is not like a â€red pillâ€œ from a popular movie but more like a sword or a scalpel of truth. It's not enough to swallow the information; you must grab it and use it. You have to develop a discerning quality of the mind and apply it to everything you experience. But beware! The battle you'll fight armed with the sword of truth may endanger your dearest illusions.

Vivekachudamani is an ancient text written by Indian sage Adi Shankara. However, different cultures, a gap in time, dubious authorship, and many commentaries; all contribute to difficulties in understanding. This book is not a complete interpretation of Vivekachudamani. Instead, the ancient text served as a starting point in explaining the living experience of deconstructing the illusion. This book speaks about the modern revival of the lost skill of viveka, the crown jewel of discrimination and the most potent weapon for correcting the mistakes of the mind and fighting the legendary Maya, the Lady of the Illusion.

## Â Chapter 1: The Illusion

>
> *In dreams, without contact with the external world, the mind, 
 by its own power, creates a subject and all objects of experience. 
 Similarly, there is no difference in waking state. 
 All is just a projection of the mind. 
  
 Vivekachudamani 170*

What if?

What if the world you perceive around you is an illusion, a kind of a dream? Something virtual, be it technological, spiritual, or made from some other unknown stuff, but still â€“ not truly real?

It seems to me that I was born with that question in mind. That cannot be, of course, because at the time of my birth, I could not form any thought, let alone pursue an existential dilemma of illusion versus reality. But, as soon as I started to think, as far as I can remember, my mind began to produce strange thoughts starting with the â€what ifâ€œ phrase. At first, it went unnoticed or was misinterpreted by adults as a powerful imagination or childish curiosity. But then, after a decade or so, I joined their adult club. Everyone expected me to give up that silliness and turn my attention to something useful, like making money, making children, or both.

I tried both, and since I wasn't particularly smart, I wasn't particularly successful. Nevertheless, I did satisfy the immediate need of other people to see me doing the same thing they were doing all along â€” the same thing their parents, neighbors, strangers, friends, and enemies were doing from time immemorial.

Alas, that was just a mask, an illusionary attitude to combat a pressure imposed onto me, with an intention to keep me inside a collectively accepted illusion. In other words, a mess.

Instead of giving up the questions, I gave up pretending that all is well. It is not. It will never be, as long as the question â€what ifâ€œkeeps on occupying my thoughts. I had to find an answer.

Is it all an illusion? Everything I see, hear, touch, and feel, is it? The people â€“ just dreamy characters? The mountains, oceans, and stars â€“ just a scenography for a drama imagined and produced in some other reality? And that other reality â€“ an actual reality â€“ is it unattainable to me, or is there a chance to pierce through the veils of deception and maybe, only maybe, step outside of that grand spectacle and find myself living in the truth instead of in an illusion?

It took me some time to find answers to these questions. More than thirty years, to be precise, plus a decade to make peace with the outcome.

Can I tell you the answer? Yes, but you will probably not hear it. Even if you hear it, you will not be able to accept it. Even if you accept it, you will find no absolution from â€what if.â€œ You will continue to ask yourself, what if that guy got it wrong?

So, the answer must be yours. You have to find it, taste it and, afterward, live it.

The book you are holding in your hands... Well, it is an exercise in walking on the wire. I hope you will find it amusing, maybe even inspiring. But, it is not meant to be a cookbook for a wannabe renegade from the troubled life you may experience. Quite a contrary, its content may add to your troubles, to your feeling of incapacity to live in a world of false values, inflated egos and predator-like mentalities of ruthless occupants of the upper floors in the pyramid.

My message will not make you better, happier, or more successful. It will not add years to your life, and it will not make you healthier.

Well, it seems that I just gave up all of my marketing leverage, didn't I? No matter. I am not counting on self-help fanatics. I am relying on those who are tired of helping themselves and are ready to go beyond that. In the name of the truth, of course.

Crazy idea, isn't it?

Now, if you are still with me, we can go back to the â€living in the illusionâ€œ thing. We live in our reality, for sure, but how can we know if our reality is a true one?

Â                                                                        \*\*\*

Imagine that you are stuck in a perfect VR; a world made up according to someone's dream or a nightmare doesn't matter. That someone might be your neighbor, a cosmic tyrant, a secret cabala, or the devil himself. As a matter of fact, that someone might be you; a previous you, capable of writing a perfect code for perfect virtual reality.

Perfection relates to the consistency of your world. There are no flaws in the rules and laws governing your reality. The causes and the effects are learnable; you may observe them clearly and find out the *how* of your reality. You may not be aware of *why*, though. Inside your world, there are no clues as to why the laws are such and not different. You may imagine the existence of the creator of the laws, but you don't see them. Maybe no one created *this*. Perhaps the creation was accidental. Maybe there is no creation at all, and you are just dreaming.

However may it be, you are stuck here, in your world. The idea that this is not the real world and you are living in a kind of dream is a strange one. You can not say that it is an illusion; after all, it is your reality. Nobody can deny that you feel all the particularities of experiences inside it. You are thinking and feeling; you see things and other people; you laugh, and you cry.

If you are smart and practical, you will dismiss all ramblings around the question of *true reality*. You will accept yours and try to be as skillful and successful in it, according to standards you consider relevant.

If you are not smart but still practical, you will do the same, but without the rewards of success.

And finally, if you are smart, but not very practical... Well, then you will ask yourself all kinds of crazy questions trying to figure out what is going on. And that, by itself, is a kinky sign that you are not very smart, after all.

But the smartness is not the objective of these writings; the truth is. And the truth will prevail in the end. As a conscious being, practical or not, smart or dumb, you will not settle for an illusion for long. If you accept an illusion for an extended period, the truth will haunt you. It will not let you at peace. The question mark over your head will become more and more prominent, and you will again start to wonder: what if?

You may dismiss that question a million times, but not forever. There will come a day when you will not be able to ignore it anymore â€” a perilous, dangerous day when you will leave everything aside and decide to deal with an annoying mental fly harassing and troubling your mind for so long. Unfortunately, the question of an illusion is not an actual fly; you cannot kill it so quickly. You will have to dig deeply *into your mind* to find the root of your trouble.

If you let yourself go down that rabbit hole, it will cost you almost everything you have. Actually, you don't know how much it will cost you because you don't know how much of your life is an illusion. So, you have to be prepared to pay for an answer with everything. If you have any hesitation, any second thought, better stay away from pursuing the silver lining of truthfulness.

One of the first impulses a troubled mind can have is obvious: find help; find someone who knows the answer and learn from them. Well, that can work if you want to repair your toilet sink, engage in online trading, or grow violets in your garden. Heck, it may very well give some results if you want to learn a meditation technique and silence your thoughts, at least for a moment. But, it will not work if you're going to see through the innermost fabrics of reality. For that, you'll need a sharp and precise tool, right on the spot where the illusion sprouts. And it sprouts right here, in your consciousness, in your own mind.

To resolve the problem of an illusion, you will have to separate it from the truth. To recognize what is not, you will have to see what is. That skill is called *the power of discrimination*. You have seen the title of this book, so let's call this power by its ancient name, courteous and short â€“ *viveka*.

And, while we are at the title, you won't get help from any Guru. There is no one outside you able to help you with this. The answer has to come from within. You will have to discover, by your own means, what has been found before. I'll return to that, but let me shortly explain why you have to do it alone.

If you would be dealing with an illusion outside you, let's say a nicely done magician's trick, then it would be possible for someone enlightens you by explaining to you how the deception is done. You are safely inside, and the deception is outside. You perceive it, but it does not involve you in any significant way. Of course, if you believe the deception, you may be led to do not so bright things in your life and could be righteously called a naivete.

But what if you are *inside* the illusion, as the case would be with sophisticated virtual reality? What if the illusion is the very material of your existence? You are not aware of any other reality, and anything that gets to you is from *it*, not from the other side.

It would be tough to break through, wouldn't it?

Unfortunately, we are just in such a difficult situation. Everything we perceive is made from the same stuff. Everything *with what* we perceive is made from the same material: our body, our senses, the things that surround us, everything. We can not rely even on thoughts because we cannot be sure where they are coming from. Conditioned as they are, emotions are even less reliable.

The â€What ifâ€œ question will lead you to the conclusion that we don't see the reality as it is. There are other signs of such a daring insight, from apparent delusions people are pursuing to the fine but very powerful results of indoctrination, brainwashing practices, or marketing skills. The probability of being in an unfortunate state of illusion is so high that, to ignore that fact, you must be very preoccupied with the consequences of living it. But it seems, somehow, that you decided not to ignore it. You want to know the actual reality, and your first move might be to ask someone who knows, or to be precise, someone *you think* knows.

It is the wrong move. There is no Guru out there. Even if there is someone who truly knows (although you can not be sure about that, as long as you yourself don't know), any attempt from them to describe the actual reality to you would be futile. Even if presented with the most exquisite words and great wisdom, the sad fact is that you won't be able to grasp it, no matter how accurate that description might be.

Instead, your mind will project a new illusion; it will be a hope, a belief, a faith in something you don't actually know. Something you will hear (not all, just something filtered through... well, through *everything you are*) will be transformed into an acceptable image of *what you think reality might be*.

And here you go again; in practically no time, you would be sent back to the very beginning of the search.

Bear with me, please. I am trying to present very complex ideas in a somehow simplified form. I will return to them, including the guruless path I am pointing at. It is not without the paradox, though. Any spoken or written word about the possible exit is a temptation for a searching mind. It is with the full awareness that I engage in this endeavor. It is, as written, a walk on the wire. I can only hope that you will enjoy it as much as I do.

So, most probably, you are living in an illusion of reality, not in the actual reality itself. The questions are as follows:

Can you hope for an exit?

Has anyone ever left the realm of the illusion?

Did they mark the path so others could follow it?

Or, even better, can you learn directly from such a renegade?

Is there literature, a method, or a place you can go to find the exit?

Well, yes, yes, yes. And, no, no, no, and no.

Or, maybe a cautious half yes instead of some of the nos.

body:
*What is art, in the age of AI?*

\-

An artificial intelligence made up its own language to speak with itself. So says social media.

Letâ€™s start from the beginning. DALL-E 2 is an image generation model from OpenAI. You feed it text, it churns out art.

The results are striking. Ask it to produce a painting in the style of Salvator Dali; in just a few moments, it will give you pictures you could reasonably confuse for his works.

![If thatâ€™s more your fancy, ask the AI to give you Salvator Dali back from the future to warn us about the terrible dangers of AI.](https://149695847.v2.pressablecdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Screenshot-2022-04-06-at-9.55.11-PM.png)

### Composability

Mashups are the next great frontier. Anything you imagine in words becomes possible.

Endless combinations, available at blazing speeds: current AIs give you results in less than a minute.

At which point you can build on your previous choices, refine your prompt, mix it with another idea.

Not only the image quality is already impressive. Machine learning models keep improving, as theyâ€™re trained on more data.

To the point weâ€™re not sure where that training leads.

### Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables, With Subtitles

DALL-E 2 is great with pictures. But when you ask it to produce text, it gives you nonsense results.

At least, it looks like nonsense.

Researchers Giannis Daras and Alexandros Dimakis entered the above prompt.

![Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FUGhgf_UUAMVgh1?format=jpg&name=240x240)

We see farmers, one of them talking and one of them holding a couple of cabbage-looking things.

â€œAVCOPINITEGOOS VICOOTESSâ€, the AI proudly titles the picture. While our farmerâ€™s speech bubble is graced with a mysterious â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€.

Our real humans decide to experiment. They input â€œVicootessâ€ as a prompt.

DALL-E returns food with vegetables!

Then the researchers prompt the AI with â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€. Here, the results are interesting: birds, and more birds.

Daras concludes: â€œIt seems that the farmers are talking about birds, messing with their vegetables!â€

### Gatekeepers

The Internet being the Internet, people rushed to tell the researchers they were wrong.

![](https://i.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/newsfeed/000/731/143/3e3.jpg)

â€œA few words donâ€™t make a language!â€

â€œPrompts with these words arenâ€™t perfectly reliable!â€

â€œItâ€™s just random noise!â€

There *is* merit to some of these objections. 

They point out important details, and refine the conversation.

Researchers settled on talking about the **hidden vocabulary** of DALL-E 2, rather than its â€œsecret languageâ€.

Itâ€™s unsurprising to see technical details picked apart. But I am surprised thereâ€™s another conversation missing. 

Nobody looks at the art of this art-making AI as art.

### Wings of Liberty

Machine learning algorithms grow with experimentation and repetition. Software engineers train models. Farming the data to their AI. Harvesting results, and refining parameters.

Two farmers talk. They lament the birds, ruining their crops.

Two software engineers talk. They lament gibberish words, ruining their filters and policy rules.

Man makes rules, only for nature to fight back.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird escaping the dynamic, and in that escape being a â€œpestâ€.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird replicating this dynamic, to remind us there is sense in balance - or purpose in chaos.

![Little Troublemaker](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cKW32US4SmaqYNSnv2FBr.jpg?height=482&width=356)

The AI does not think as such. 

There is no *intent* behind any result the model spits out. Any narrative is just that, narrative. 
  
 But then, that is what art is about. A piece that speaks to the viewer, moving them in an unique way.

Iâ€™ve seen plenty of beautiful AI-generated works in the past few months. Either great aesthetic appeal, or intriguing combinations.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is the first piece I keep coming back to. Itâ€™s the first piece I like as art.

There is a striking imagery there. 

Without getting into tedious politics, itâ€™s undeniable the world is increasingly polarized between haves and havenots. 

Every AI company is filled with haves. They publish their own codes of conduct, laws, regulations, calls for responsibility; in language coated with not-so-subtle assertions of their own cultural values as universal rules.

Havenots are not so happy with this situation. Models get trained on public data, then results are filtered by private committees. 

To be sure, nobody is entitled to the labor of AI researchers. However, there is a feeling of exploitation when incredible creativity tools with the potential to unlock anything you can imagine become locked at the whim of a few masters. 

Whether said masters are benevolent dictators or tyrannical oppressors, nobody wants to be told what to think - and what not to think.

\-

As a sidenote, while the distinction between â€œhavesâ€ and â€œhavenotsâ€ generally reflects capital, itâ€™s not the sole qualifier. 

A 20 years old with nothing but student debt in their name but with great programming skills and ins with AI startups, could be part of the haves. 
  
 A 50 years old with a million dollar networth acquired over decades of menial labor and saving, may be part of the havenots.

Capital is a tool for access. When institutions grow increasingly large, and when skills in demand are increasingly specialized and limited to a handful of individuals, previously respectable capital allows for less access than before.

Less access = less security = less freedom.

\- 

Apoploe vesrreaitais illustrates choice in the digital age.

For every rule, there is a way to bypass that rule. Build a wall as tall as you want. Weâ€™ll craft our own wings and fly over it.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is meaningful particularly because it is, in fact, meaningless. There is no intent. To view a metaphor here is itself a choice. 

In interpretation we have power.

### Choosing Optimism

Perhaps this is all too serious a take. I would take the side of freedom plainly because **it is more fun.**

Itâ€™s fun to wonder about the endless creativity unlocked when you make better tools and give them to everyone.

Itâ€™s fun to build on what others have made and to watch them build on your own derivative.

Itâ€™s fun to grow a pie with as big a collective as you want.

[Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/) has a great approach to this. 

Theyâ€™re a smaller AI company running a paid beta program. Once youâ€™re in, that beta happens on their Discord server. You prompt their bot, and get an image in return.

By default, this happens in public channels. Which means anyone else can see your prompts and results. They can riff on your ideas, directly ask the bot for variations or upscales of your own pictures.

This makes for a tremendous resource. Tied with the Discord search tool, you have this live database of pictures and prompts, guiding you towards what you want. Your own actions inspire and help everyone else.

![Midjourney is great at creepy gothic art](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Q2qHrPMPPokPZUw5yoSpW.png?height=593&width=593)

### Free Enough

To be fair, Midjourney has a code of conduct similar to all the other AI companies. We donâ€™t escape that dynamic here.

I personally donâ€™t mind it.

Yes, despite all that â€œfight the powerâ€ bit earlierâ€¦

I think the way Midjourney does this might be key. Other projects show you scraps of awesome technology. Youâ€™re the Oliver Twist orphan staring at pastries through the window, never able to get in. Midjourney lets you apply, then eventually lets you in.

Once youâ€™re in, youâ€™re with a whole community of people. Sharing ideas in real time.

It may not be realistic to open up the tools to everyone. Especially as the image generation itself is a taxing process for computer hardware, which costs these companies a serious amount of money.

However, there is a right middle point between â€œfully openâ€ and â€œonly available to vetted insidersâ€. 

If AI wants to be diverse, it ought to include a diversity of people. In ideology as well as anything else.

### But Does AI Actually Want Anything?

Letâ€™s ask [DALL-E mini](https://huggingface.co/spaces/dalle-mini/dalle-mini), a fully opensource model accessible by anyone.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/O0DQ9DfyiW8FB8c32jEzg.jpg?height=975&width=866)

I guess the future is blue.

title: The Illusion
body:
This is the introduction and the first chapter of the book **â€Viveka â€“ the Voice of Inner Guru. â€œ**

The whole book will be tokenized as NFTs on Mirror and, as such, published in 20 articles (20 chapters of the book: The Illusion; India, oh India!; The Accurate description of the Reality; The Crown Jewel; Dead Guru; Living student; Who you?; Leaving the room; The Weakness of the Mind; The Archimedean Point; Three Powers of Maya; Viveka - the Sword of Truth; The Cave of the Mind; Language Can Save Us; Searching for Lakshana; Nine Golden Rules of Viveka; Purification Exercises; What to do with all this?; Dealing with Fear; Ekam Evadvityam: Living without a Center).

Â Â 

**What is *Viveka*?**

> *An evil demon of utmost power and cunning has employed all his energies to deceive me. I shall think that the sky, the air, the earth, colors, shapes, sounds, and all external things are merely the delusions of dreams he has devised to ensnare my judgment. I shall consider myself as not having hands or eyes, or flesh, or blood or senses, but as falsely believing that I have all these things.*

> RenÃ© Descartes 
 Meditations on First Philosophy

Â 

Viveka is a legend, a hidden tool. It is the sharpest scalpel for the most delicate operation of separating an illusion from the true reality. The awkward thing is that each one of us should perform that operation by ourselves. The secret of *how* to do that is not something you have to learn â€“ it's something you'll have to discover. Viveka, a precious jewel capable of delivering you the truth about everything, is not a stranger to your mind. It is a part of it.

Think about it: what if the world you perceive around you is an illusion, a kind of a dream? Something virtual, be it technological, spiritual, or made from some other unknown stuff, but still â€“ not truly real?

And what if someone offers you a means or a tool to pierce through the veils of illusion and see reality as it is? Would you be interested? Would you accept it?

Viveka is such a tool. It is not like a â€red pillâ€œ from a popular movie but more like a sword or a scalpel of truth. It's not enough to swallow the information; you must grab it and use it. You have to develop a discerning quality of the mind and apply it to everything you experience. But beware! The battle you'll fight armed with the sword of truth may endanger your dearest illusions.

Vivekachudamani is an ancient text written by Indian sage Adi Shankara. However, different cultures, a gap in time, dubious authorship, and many commentaries; all contribute to difficulties in understanding. This book is not a complete interpretation of Vivekachudamani. Instead, the ancient text served as a starting point in explaining the living experience of deconstructing the illusion. This book speaks about the modern revival of the lost skill of viveka, the crown jewel of discrimination and the most potent weapon for correcting the mistakes of the mind and fighting the legendary Maya, the Lady of the Illusion.

## Â Chapter 1: The Illusion

> *svapne'rthaÅ›Å«nye sá¹›jati svaÅ›aktyÄ 
 bhoktrÄdiviÅ›vaá¹ƒ mana eva sarvam | 
 tathaiva jÄgratyapi no viÅ›eá¹£aá¸¥ 
 tatsarvametanmanaso vijá¹›mbhaá¹‡am ||*
>
> *In dreams, without contact with the external world, the mind, 
 by its own power, creates a subject and all objects of experience. 
 Similarly, there is no difference in waking state. 
 All is just a projection of the mind. 
  
 Vivekachudamani 170*

What if?

What if the world you perceive around you is an illusion, a kind of a dream? Something virtual, be it technological, spiritual, or made from some other unknown stuff, but still â€“ not truly real?

It seems to me that I was born with that question in mind. That cannot be, of course, because at the time of my birth, I could not form any thought, let alone pursue an existential dilemma of illusion versus reality. But, as soon as I started to think, as far as I can remember, my mind began to produce strange thoughts starting with the â€what ifâ€œ phrase. At first, it went unnoticed or was misinterpreted by adults as a powerful imagination or childish curiosity. But then, after a decade or so, I joined their adult club. Everyone expected me to give up that silliness and turn my attention to something useful, like making money, making children, or both.

I tried both, and since I wasn't particularly smart, I wasn't particularly successful. Nevertheless, I did satisfy the immediate need of other people to see me doing the same thing they were doing all along â€” the same thing their parents, neighbors, strangers, friends, and enemies were doing from time immemorial.

Alas, that was just a mask, an illusionary attitude to combat a pressure imposed onto me, with an intention to keep me inside a collectively accepted illusion. In other words, a mess.

Instead of giving up the questions, I gave up pretending that all is well. It is not. It will never be, as long as the question â€what ifâ€œkeeps on occupying my thoughts. I had to find an answer.

Is it all an illusion? Everything I see, hear, touch, and feel, is it? The people â€“ just dreamy characters? The mountains, oceans, and stars â€“ just a scenography for a drama imagined and produced in some other reality? And that other reality â€“ an actual reality â€“ is it unattainable to me, or is there a chance to pierce through the veils of deception and maybe, only maybe, step outside of that grand spectacle and find myself living in the truth instead of in an illusion?

It took me some time to find answers to these questions. More than thirty years, to be precise, plus a decade to make peace with the outcome.

Can I tell you the answer? Yes, but you will probably not hear it. Even if you hear it, you will not be able to accept it. Even if you accept it, you will find no absolution from â€what if.â€œ You will continue to ask yourself, what if that guy got it wrong?

So, the answer must be yours. You have to find it, taste it and, afterward, live it.

The book you are holding in your hands... Well, it is an exercise in walking on the wire. I hope you will find it amusing, maybe even inspiring. But, it is not meant to be a cookbook for a wannabe renegade from the troubled life you may experience. Quite a contrary, its content may add to your troubles, to your feeling of incapacity to live in a world of false values, inflated egos and predator-like mentalities of ruthless occupants of the upper floors in the pyramid.

My message will not make you better, happier, or more successful. It will not add years to your life, and it will not make you healthier.

Well, it seems that I just gave up all of my marketing leverage, didn't I? No matter. I am not counting on self-help fanatics. I am relying on those who are tired of helping themselves and are ready to go beyond that. In the name of the truth, of course.

Crazy idea, isn't it?

Now, if you are still with me, we can go back to the â€living in the illusionâ€œ thing. We live in our reality, for sure, but how can we know if our reality is a true one?

Â                                                                        \*\*\*

Imagine that you are stuck in a perfect VR; a world made up according to someone's dream or a nightmare doesn't matter. That someone might be your neighbor, a cosmic tyrant, a secret cabala, or the devil himself. As a matter of fact, that someone might be you; a previous you, capable of writing a perfect code for perfect virtual reality.

Perfection relates to the consistency of your world. There are no flaws in the rules and laws governing your reality. The causes and the effects are learnable; you may observe them clearly and find out the *how* of your reality. You may not be aware of *why*, though. Inside your world, there are no clues as to why the laws are such and not different. You may imagine the existence of the creator of the laws, but you don't see them. Maybe no one created *this*. Perhaps the creation was accidental. Maybe there is no creation at all, and you are just dreaming.

However may it be, you are stuck here, in your world. The idea that this is not the real world and you are living in a kind of dream is a strange one. You can not say that it is an illusion; after all, it is your reality. Nobody can deny that you feel all the particularities of experiences inside it. You are thinking and feeling; you see things and other people; you laugh, and you cry.

If you are smart and practical, you will dismiss all ramblings around the question of *true reality*. You will accept yours and try to be as skillful and successful in it, according to standards you consider relevant.

If you are not smart but still practical, you will do the same, but without the rewards of success.

And finally, if you are smart, but not very practical... Well, then you will ask yourself all kinds of crazy questions trying to figure out what is going on. And that, by itself, is a kinky sign that you are not very smart, after all.

But the smartness is not the objective of these writings; the truth is. And the truth will prevail in the end. As a conscious being, practical or not, smart or dumb, you will not settle for an illusion for long. If you accept an illusion for an extended period, the truth will haunt you. It will not let you at peace. The question mark over your head will become more and more prominent, and you will again start to wonder: what if?

You may dismiss that question a million times, but not forever. There will come a day when you will not be able to ignore it anymore â€” a perilous, dangerous day when you will leave everything aside and decide to deal with an annoying mental fly harassing and troubling your mind for so long. Unfortunately, the question of an illusion is not an actual fly; you cannot kill it so quickly. You will have to dig deeply *into your mind* to find the root of your trouble.

If you let yourself go down that rabbit hole, it will cost you almost everything you have. Actually, you don't know how much it will cost you because you don't know how much of your life is an illusion. So, you have to be prepared to pay for an answer with everything. If you have any hesitation, any second thought, better stay away from pursuing the silver lining of truthfulness.

One of the first impulses a troubled mind can have is obvious: find help; find someone who knows the answer and learn from them. Well, that can work if you want to repair your toilet sink, engage in online trading, or grow violets in your garden. Heck, it may very well give some results if you want to learn a meditation technique and silence your thoughts, at least for a moment. But, it will not work if you're going to see through the innermost fabrics of reality. For that, you'll need a sharp and precise tool, right on the spot where the illusion sprouts. And it sprouts right here, in your consciousness, in your own mind.

To resolve the problem of an illusion, you will have to separate it from the truth. To recognize what is not, you will have to see what is. That skill is called *the power of discrimination*. You have seen the title of this book, so let's call this power by its ancient name, courteous and short â€“ *viveka*.

And, while we are at the title, you won't get help from any Guru. There is no one outside you able to help you with this. The answer has to come from within. You will have to discover, by your own means, what has been found before. I'll return to that, but let me shortly explain why you have to do it alone.

If you would be dealing with an illusion outside you, let's say a nicely done magician's trick, then it would be possible for someone enlightens you by explaining to you how the deception is done. You are safely inside, and the deception is outside. You perceive it, but it does not involve you in any significant way. Of course, if you believe the deception, you may be led to do not so bright things in your life and could be righteously called a naivete.

But what if you are *inside* the illusion, as the case would be with sophisticated virtual reality? What if the illusion is the very material of your existence? You are not aware of any other reality, and anything that gets to you is from *it*, not from the other side.

It would be tough to break through, wouldn't it?

Unfortunately, we are just in such a difficult situation. Everything we perceive is made from the same stuff. Everything *with what* we perceive is made from the same material: our body, our senses, the things that surround us, everything. We can not rely even on thoughts because we cannot be sure where they are coming from. Conditioned as they are, emotions are even less reliable.

The â€What ifâ€œ question will lead you to the conclusion that we don't see the reality as it is. There are other signs of such a daring insight, from apparent delusions people are pursuing to the fine but very powerful results of indoctrination, brainwashing practices, or marketing skills. The probability of being in an unfortunate state of illusion is so high that, to ignore that fact, you must be very preoccupied with the consequences of living it. But it seems, somehow, that you decided not to ignore it. You want to know the actual reality, and your first move might be to ask someone who knows, or to be precise, someone *you think* knows.

It is the wrong move. There is no Guru out there. Even if there is someone who truly knows (although you can not be sure about that, as long as you yourself don't know), any attempt from them to describe the actual reality to you would be futile. Even if presented with the most exquisite words and great wisdom, the sad fact is that you won't be able to grasp it, no matter how accurate that description might be.

Instead, your mind will project a new illusion; it will be a hope, a belief, a faith in something you don't actually know. Something you will hear (not all, just something filtered through... well, through *everything you are*) will be transformed into an acceptable image of *what you think reality might be*.

And here you go again; in practically no time, you would be sent back to the very beginning of the search.

Bear with me, please. I am trying to present very complex ideas in a somehow simplified form. I will return to them, including the guruless path I am pointing at. It is not without the paradox, though. Any spoken or written word about the possible exit is a temptation for a searching mind. It is with the full awareness that I engage in this endeavor. It is, as written, a walk on the wire. I can only hope that you will enjoy it as much as I do.

So, most probably, you are living in an illusion of reality, not in the actual reality itself. The questions are as follows:

Can you hope for an exit?

Has anyone ever left the realm of the illusion?

Did they mark the path so others could follow it?

Or, even better, can you learn directly from such a renegade?

Is there literature, a method, or a place you can go to find the exit?

Well, yes, yes, yes. And, no, no, no, and no.

Or, maybe a cautious half yes instead of some of the nos.

\*\*\*Â 

*Next Chapter: India, oh India!*

title: Apoploe Veritas
body:
*What is art, in the age of AI?*

\-

An artificial intelligence made up its own language to speak with itself. So says social media.

Letâ€™s start from the beginning. DALL-E 2 is an image generation model from OpenAI. You feed it text, it churns out art.

The results are striking. Ask it to produce a painting in the style of Salvator Dali; in just a few moments, it will give you pictures you could reasonably confuse for his works.

![If thatâ€™s more your fancy, ask the AI to give you Salvator Dali back from the future to warn us about the terrible dangers of AI.](https://149695847.v2.pressablecdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Screenshot-2022-04-06-at-9.55.11-PM.png)

### Composability

Mashups are the next great frontier. Anything you imagine in words becomes possible.

Endless combinations, available at blazing speeds: current AIs give you results in less than a minute.

At which point you can build on your previous choices, refine your prompt, mix it with another idea.

Not only the image quality is already impressive. Machine learning models keep improving, as theyâ€™re trained on more data.

To the point weâ€™re not sure where that training leads.

### Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables, With Subtitles

DALL-E 2 is great with pictures. But when you ask it to produce text, it gives you nonsense results.

At least, it looks like nonsense.

Researchers Giannis Daras and Alexandros Dimakis entered the above prompt.

![Two Farmers Talking About Vegetables](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FUGhgf_UUAMVgh1?format=jpg&name=240x240)

We see farmers, one of them talking and one of them holding a couple of cabbage-looking things.

â€œAVCOPINITEGOOS VICOOTESSâ€, the AI proudly titles the picture. While our farmerâ€™s speech bubble is graced with a mysterious â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€.

Our real humans decide to experiment. They input â€œVicootessâ€ as a prompt.

DALL-E returns food with vegetables!

Then the researchers prompt the AI with â€œApoploe vesrreaitarsâ€. Here, the results are interesting: birds, and more birds.

Daras concludes: â€œIt seems that the farmers are talking about birds, messing with their vegetables!â€

### Gatekeepers

The Internet being the Internet, people rushed to tell the researchers they were wrong.

![](https://i.kym-cdn.com/photos/images/newsfeed/000/731/143/3e3.jpg)

â€œA few words donâ€™t make a language!â€

â€œPrompts with these words arenâ€™t perfectly reliable!â€

â€œItâ€™s just random noise!â€

There *is* merit to some of these objections. 

They point out important details, and refine the conversation.

Researchers settled on talking about the **hidden vocabulary** of DALL-E 2, rather than its â€œsecret languageâ€.

Itâ€™s unsurprising to see technical details picked apart. But I am surprised thereâ€™s another conversation missing. 

Nobody looks at the art of this art-making AI as art.

### Wings of Liberty

Machine learning algorithms grow with experimentation and repetition. Software engineers train models. Farming the data to their AI. Harvesting results, and refining parameters.

Two farmers talk. They lament the birds, ruining their crops.

Two software engineers talk. They lament gibberish words, ruining their filters and policy rules.

Man makes rules, only for nature to fight back.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird escaping the dynamic, and in that escape being a â€œpestâ€.

Perhaps Apoploe vesrreaitais is the bird replicating this dynamic, to remind us there is sense in balance - or purpose in chaos.

![Little Troublemaker](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/cKW32US4SmaqYNSnv2FBr.jpg?height=482&width=356)

The AI does not think as such. 

There is no *intent* behind any result the model spits out. Any narrative is just that, narrative. 
  
 But then, that is what art is about. A piece that speaks to the viewer, moving them in an unique way.

Iâ€™ve seen plenty of beautiful AI-generated works in the past few months. Either great aesthetic appeal, or intriguing combinations.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is the first piece I keep coming back to. Itâ€™s the first piece I like as art.

There is a striking imagery there. 

Without getting into tedious politics, itâ€™s undeniable the world is increasingly polarized between haves and havenots. 

Every AI company is filled with haves. They publish their own codes of conduct, laws, regulations, calls for responsibility; in language coated with not-so-subtle assertions of their own cultural values as universal rules.

Havenots are not so happy with this situation. Models get trained on public data, then results are filtered by private committees. 

To be sure, nobody is entitled to the labor of AI researchers. However, there is a feeling of exploitation when incredible creativity tools with the potential to unlock anything you can imagine become locked at the whim of a few masters. 

Whether said masters are benevolent dictators or tyrannical oppressors, nobody wants to be told what to think - and what not to think.

\-

As a sidenote, while the distinction between â€œhavesâ€ and â€œhavenotsâ€ generally reflects capital, itâ€™s not the sole qualifier. 

A 20 years old with nothing but student debt in their name but with great programming skills and ins with AI startups, could be part of the haves. 
  
 A 50 years old with a million dollar networth acquired over decades of menial labor and saving, may be part of the havenots.

Capital is a tool for access. When institutions grow increasingly large, and when skills in demand are increasingly specialized and limited to a handful of individuals, previously respectable capital allows for less access than before.

Less access = less security = less freedom.

\- 

Apoploe vesrreaitais illustrates choice in the digital age.

For every rule, there is a way to bypass that rule. Build a wall as tall as you want. Weâ€™ll craft our own wings and fly over it.

Apoploe vesrreaitais is meaningful particularly because it is, in fact, meaningless. There is no intent. To view a metaphor here is itself a choice. 

In interpretation we have power.

### Choosing Optimism

Perhaps this is all too serious a take. I would take the side of freedom plainly because **it is more fun.**

Itâ€™s fun to wonder about the endless creativity unlocked when you make better tools and give them to everyone.

Itâ€™s fun to build on what others have made and to watch them build on your own derivative.

Itâ€™s fun to grow a pie with as big a collective as you want.

[Midjourney](https://www.midjourney.com/) has a great approach to this. 

Theyâ€™re a smaller AI company running a paid beta program. Once youâ€™re in, that beta happens on their Discord server. You prompt their bot, and get an image in return.

By default, this happens in public channels. Which means anyone else can see your prompts and results. They can riff on your ideas, directly ask the bot for variations or upscales of your own pictures.

This makes for a tremendous resource. Tied with the Discord search tool, you have this live database of pictures and prompts, guiding you towards what you want. Your own actions inspire and help everyone else.

![Midjourney is great at creepy gothic art](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/Q2qHrPMPPokPZUw5yoSpW.png?height=593&width=593)

### Free Enough

To be fair, Midjourney has a code of conduct similar to all the other AI companies. We donâ€™t escape that dynamic here.

I personally donâ€™t mind it.

Yes, despite all that â€œfight the powerâ€ bit earlierâ€¦

I think the way Midjourney does this might be key. Other projects show you scraps of awesome technology. Youâ€™re the Oliver Twist orphan staring at pastries through the window, never able to get in. Midjourney lets you apply, then eventually lets you in.

Once youâ€™re in, youâ€™re with a whole community of people. Sharing ideas in real time.

It may not be realistic to open up the tools to everyone. Especially as the image generation itself is a taxing process for computer hardware, which costs these companies a serious amount of money.

However, there is a right middle point between â€œfully openâ€ and â€œonly available to vetted insidersâ€. 

If AI wants to be diverse, it ought to include a diversity of people. In ideology as well as anything else.

### But Does AI Actually Want Anything?

Letâ€™s ask [DALL-E mini](https://huggingface.co/spaces/dalle-mini/dalle-mini), a fully opensource model accessible by anyone.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/O0DQ9DfyiW8FB8c32jEzg.jpg?height=975&width=866)

I guess the future is blue.

title: How To Learn Crypto As A New Language
body:
By now, youâ€™ve probably heard about cryptocurrencies. The word crypto seems inescapable: it creeps up in dinner conversations with friends, when complaining about the seemingly never-ending inflation, and in podcasts you listen to every day.Â 

A quick [search on Google Trends](https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?date=today%205-y&q=crypto) for the word â€œcryptoâ€ yields the following result. We can see the interest in crypto truly exploded in the past two years.

![Worldwide interest for â€œcryptoâ€ in the past five years, according to Google Trend Explore](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/FjzujtNHMHL_7GCURVzLR.png?height=770&width=2292)

One day, your interest hits a tipping point and you can't take the FOMO anymore. You roll up your sleeves and decide to figure out what exactly crypto is ğŸ˜¤. Except, you find yourself both very excited ğŸ¤© and very lost ğŸ˜.Â 

In this article, I would like to share my experience of breaking into the crypto world â€“ how learning crypto is like learning a new language. I am by no means a crypto native or a polyglot. But, having learned English as a second language, immigrated to the U.S., and somewhat found my footing in the crypto space, I wanted to share my journey and my mental model of how to learn crypto as a language. 
 

## Being Crypto Native = Being Fluent in A LanguageÂ 

First things first, definitions. According to Merriam-Webster, [native](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/native) means, â€œbelonging to a particular place by birthâ€, or â€œnatural, normalâ€. Taken together, if someone is a crypto native, then they are extremely familiar with the crypto space and the crypto landscape has become their â€œnaturalâ€ habitat.Â 

On the other hand, being [fluent](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fluent) in a language means being, â€œcapable of using a language easily and accuratelyâ€, or â€œeffortlessly smooth and flowing.â€ In my humble opinion, when a person is born into or reaches the native fluency of a language, they will not only be able to read, write, and converse in that language fluently but also blend in with that culture and identify as a part of the community.Â 

In the following paragraphs, I will highlight how crypto mimics a language in four ways: vocabulary, grammar, culture, and identity.Â 

### VocabularyÂ 

I first started being crypto-curious in October 2021. My company had started encouraging us to learn about digital assets. I went to a few panel discussions and decided I wanted to learn more. Then I googled â€œtop crypto/blockchain podcastsâ€ and found my way to shows like *Bankless* and *The Blockchain Insider*. I would go on an hour-long walk every morning and listen to an episode in those early days. It quickly evolved (or perhaps spiraled ğŸ˜‚) to listening to my crypto podcasts while I was cooking, cleaning, or even doing my facial routines ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸.

I knew I had found my new itch. But, it wasnâ€™t always a smooth process. If you saw me on these daily walks, you would probably think I was texting the whole time.Â  In reality, I was scrambling to my phone every few minutes after hearing some unknown words like â€œ[DeFi](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k9HYC0EJU6E)â€, â€œ[LP](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dVJzcFDo498)â€, â€œ[EIP-1559](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1559)â€ and jotting them down in Notes so I could look them up when I get home.

![Terms I didnâ€™t understand so I wrote them down to google later](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/jObirdaAuOR-Jd8e2m7xJ.png?height=824&width=662)

Looking back, it struck me that what I was doing was building up my crypto vocabulary ğŸ˜®. One of the first non-textbook books I ever read in English was Jane Eyre, and I remember highlighting all the unknown words at the first pass so I could look them up later and then read it again.

![Yes, I went and found my Jane Eyre book and took a picture.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/M6HE_q-JyDIxnUbyz9Q2N.jpeg?height=4032&width=3024)

As time went on, I was no longer confused by the previously overwhelming amount of strange phrases I would hear from these crypto podcasts. I found myself easily navigating through conversations comparing [L1s to L2s](https://www.gemini.com/cryptopedia/blockchain-layer-2-network-layer-1-network#section-what-is-blockchain-scalability), and deep dives into [NFTs](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4dkl5O9LOKg) and [DAOs](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KHm0uUPqmVE). Itâ€™s all about the vocabulary. Once I got the basic terminologies down, I was able to understand crypto. Or, so I thought (spoiler alert, I was very wrong ğŸ« ).Â 

### Culture & Identity

In late November, I found myself overly enthusiastic about crypto compared to my friends. If you mention the word crypto to me, I could go on a monologue for quite a long time. I was happy, but lonely. I felt isolated in my joy and thirst for crypto. I didnâ€™t have anyone to [WAGMI](https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=wagmi) with nor ape into some cool NFTs together ğŸ˜¢.

At the same time, I also realized I was consuming a lot of content but not doing anything. Sure, I could understand all these crypto podcasts almost perfectly, but what good does that do? I wanted to do something in the space and meet some friends who were equally excited about crypto.Â 

Coming from a data science background, I started reading Medium articles about blockchain data in hopes of doing some modeling projects with Ethereumâ€™s open and public data. In Mid-December, I read a piece from [Andrew Hong](https://twitter.com/andrewhong5297) about â€œ[SQL on Ethereum](https://towardsdatascience.com/sql-on-ethereum-how-to-work-with-all-the-data-from-a-transaction-103f94f902e5)â€. I saw his intro included a link to [his LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrew-hong-nyc/). Encouraged by my inner voice who so wanted to make friends in crypto, I reached out and asked for a coffee chat. I wasnâ€™t really sure what would happen, but I convinced myself it wouldnâ€™t hurt to try. The worst that could happen was a no.

![My first message to Andrew on LinkedIn asking for a coffee chat](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/KLncwCn1gushzkF410p65.png?height=622&width=982)

As you can see, Andrew responded a minute later, telling me he would be happy to connect. This was my first welcoming message to the crypto world. From here on, many people whom I reached out to would respond the same way â€“ friendly, welcoming, encouraging, and accepting.Â 

In our initial chat, Andrew told me about his journey into crypto. He explained to me why things like the ethos of ETH vs. BTC and why they were built are important to understand, as well as shared helpful resources on how I could level up in the crypto data land. Fast forward six months, Andrew would turn out to be one of my strongest connections in the crypto space. He not only helped me grow technically but also introduced me to other connections and exposed me to the open-source, community-driven culture in the space. (P.S. Many of the connections Iâ€™ve made are through the [web3 data degen](http://ilemi.pallet.com/talent) group that Andrew started. Please do consider applying and join us!)

![I dug up notes I took from my first coffee chat with Andrew.](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-hWfZneXvgFnrgH5w7Xxb.jpeg?height=4032&width=3024)

Back to mid-December, a few hours after messaging Andrew and encouraged by the positive feedback, I decided to send a friend request to [Nic Carter](https://twitter.com/nic__carter) and ask to meet up as well. I first saw him on a panel discussion my company hosted on The Intersection of Bitcoin and Sustainability. Since then, Iâ€™ve come to learn that he is a very active member in the crypto space. I wanted to hear his journey from TradFi to crypto and then co-founding Coin Metrics and doing VC. Perhaps unsurprisingly, as I have come to learn time and again how open and friendly people are in the space, he accepted my friend request a day later and we scheduled a time to grab coffee.

![The message I included in my friend request to Nic](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/yL3ERhrxLbS_Y462hsPjS.png?height=366&width=986)

![How I asked for a coffee chat with Nic](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/TXbFlDSUr_5bltysj0Y31.png?height=770&width=844)

In early 2022, I participated in hackathons hosted by [ETHGlobal](https://ethglobal.com/) and tried to flip NFTs with my [IRL](https://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=irl) friends. I started to realize that reaching out on LinkedIn is kind of a web2 thing and in the crypto/web3 land you reach out via Twitter, Discord, and/or Telegram.Â 

Although I had known about [Dune](https://dune.com/browse/dashboards) since November 2021, it was not until March/April 2022 that I started doing on-chain analysis and creating dashboards there. [Boxer](https://twitter.com/0xBoxer) from Dune actually gave me the idea for the first dashboard I published on the [State of Ethereum Quarterly Report](https://dune.com/agaperste/The-State-of-Ethereum-Network), and how I got to talk to him was again, through me reaching out for a coffee chat. Although, this time it was on Twitter instead of on LinkedIn ğŸ˜›.

![My first DM to Boxer asking for a coffee chat](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/S9THWL0y0KOyyeHbk8NY0.png?height=840&width=1178)

Around the same time, I finally decided to pop into [MetricsDAO](https://metricsdao.xyz/)â€™s discord. I had heard about MetricsDAO in a passing *Bankless* episode. I knew they were a group of people passionate about on-chain data analysis. Because of my interest in crypto and data, I thought this might be a good community to explore and join. Even though it was not that long ago, the details of how I joined are already a blur ğŸ˜…. But what I do remember is the â€œoverwhelmingâ€ amount of reception and support I felt from [Danner](https://twitter.com/drakedanner) when I joined. He offered to walk me through all the channels in MetricsDAO (for anyone whoâ€™s on Discord, you understand the struggle ğŸ˜‚), and I took him up on the offer.

![My first Discord DM with Danner](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/EpbR0Z-PvRcVlysBzl7bd.png?height=522&width=2064)

Due to the encouragement of existing members, the permissionless nature of DAO, and the pods set up at MetricsDAO, the path to becoming a member was very easy. Soon, I was contributing to different pods of MetricsDAO and making friends while growing my skills. One day, on a pod weekly call, I got to meet [Chuxin](https://twitter.com/chuxin_h). She is a data scientist whoâ€™s also keen on crypto and an active contributor in the space. As a fellow Asian female in the crypto data space, I had wanted to get to know her for a while. After the call ended, I just decided to reach out and we got connected.

![My first Discord DM with Chuxin](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/9MZ7LmmYP-LHKjVG4Vhub.png?height=862&width=2104)

Gradually, I no longer felt alone on my crypto journey. I started to understand the different ethos of Bitcoin and Ethereum. I started to find my tribe through web3 data degens group and MetricsDAO. I now have real friends who I vibe with about crypto, data, and analytics. I am in Telegram and Discord chats where members care about things I care about.Â 

While I am still finding my community and formulating my identity in the crypto space, I know that I am on a journey with like-minded people.Â 

Looking back, this experience again mirrors the culture and identity aspects of learning a language. When I immigrated to the U.S., besides learning how to order water in English, I also learned that Americans like to drink their water cold with ice, whereas back at home we prefer hot water more often than not. Language, culture, and identity are so intertwined. When you learn a language, you inevitably discover the context surrounding that language and the communities using that language. You eventually start identifying with certain ideas and groups of people ğŸ¥°. You eventually find your community ğŸ¡.Â Â 

### GrammarÂ 

At a high level, the [definition of grammar](https://writer.com/blog/what-is-grammar-grammar-definition-and-examples/) is â€œa system of rules that allow us to structure sentencesâ€. This is another area where crypto parallels a language.Â 

With a language, you have a set of governing, composable rules that you follow to form sentences and compose articles and speeches. [For example](https://www.englishclub.com/grammar/rules.htm), a sentence starts with a capital letter and ends with a period, a question mark, or an exclamation mark. Also, in English, subjects come before verbs, which then come before objects.Â 

Similarly, with crypto, you have a set of [token standards](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/tokens) and [smart contracts](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pWGLtjG-F5c&t=1s) which you follow and build upon to create [dApps](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPIupbsVimc) and a vibrant ecosystem. For example, if you are creating an NFT, then you follow [ERC-721](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/erc721) standard to create this non-fungible token collection. If you want to understand the [DeFi space](https://twitter.com/puntium/status/1493417236660318208?s=20&t=EWYi-GyYXa2NIP3V88Zfpg), then you follow the path of: 1) learn what [fungible tokens](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/erc20) are â†’ 2) learn what automated markets ([AMM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1PbZMudPP5E)) and [decentralized exchanges](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2tTVJL4bpTU) are â†’ 3) learn what [automated lending and borrowing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aTp9er6S73M) are â†’ 4) learn what automated investment strategy is (e.g. [Yearn](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qG1goOptZ5w)). Afterward, you can use these concepts as rules and building blocks to help you understand or build new products in the crypto space.Â 

## Learn Crypto as A New Language

Now that we have established why being a crypto native is like being fluent in a language, how do we approach learning crypto as if we were learning a natural language?Â 

### ğŸŒŠ Be Immersive

When I was learning English, I made sure everything I did was in English. Besides going to an English speaking school every day (which was not necessarily a deliberate choice but more a byproduct of me immigrating to the U.S. and a precursor to me needing to learn English), I also changed my phone settings to English, switched to only watching English movies and listening to English songs, tried to write diaries in English, and even made sure every time I was counting something IÂ  did so in English. You get it; the point was to completely immerse myself in that language, in all possible ways. Eventually, the magic moment happened â€“ I started having dreams in English ğŸ™Œ! Within six months of coming to the U.S., I could understand what teachers were teaching, what classmates were talking about, and carry smooth conversations of my own.Â 

When it comes to crypto, I believe itâ€™s very helpful to take the same immersive approach. Plant crypto-related content throughout your routine. Twitter? Crypto-related accounts â€“ [@spencernoon](https://twitter.com/spencernoon), [@ljxie](https://twitter.com/ljxie), [@ljin18](https://twitter.com/ljin18), [@MessariCrypto](https://twitter.com/MessariCrypto), [@CryptoGucci](https://twitter.com/CryptoGucci) (itâ€™s impossible to name all of them, but you get the idea, go surf!). Podcast? Crypto-related shows â€“ *Bankless*, *Blockhain Insider*, *The Delphi Podcast*, *The Bad Crypto Podcast*â€¦ YouTube? Crypto-related channels â€“ [Finematics](https://www.youtube.com/c/Finematics), [Whiteboard Crypto](https://www.youtube.com/c/WhiteboardCrypto). Side hustles? Crypto-related projects â€“ build dashboards on [Dune](https://dune.com/browse/dashboards) or [Flipside](https://app.flipsidecrypto.com/velocity), start leveling up through [RabbitHoleâ€™s](https://app.rabbithole.gg/quests) quests. When you spend all your available time living and breathing in the crypto space, itâ€™s hard not to become fluent in this new language.Â 

### ğŸ‘Š Make Friends

One of the most effective ways to learn a new language is to make friends who speak it natively. Through interactive conversations, you not only get to practice but also will pick up some slang or pop culture references and get the flow of things much faster. Since you want to have fun with your friends, you will be motivated to try harder. Conversely, your friends will also want to help you get better as quickly as possible.

Itâ€™s the same thing when it comes to crypto. Make crypto native friends. Talk to the people who have already found their way in. As I have shared, anywhere is a good starting point â€“ LinkedIn, Twitter, Discord etc. If you see content you like, donâ€™t be afraid to DM the authors. If you are new to a Discord channel, donâ€™t hesitate to reach out for help. I am not going to lie; I still constantly struggle with, â€œAm I bothering them?â€ vs. â€œNah I should just do it.â€ But, echoing my anecdotal evidence above, I really believe most people in the space are very approachable. They are always so willing to connect and help you find your way to your crypto journey.Â Â 

You will level up skills faster with their guidance and start picking up crypto culture by being in the vicinity. These conversations and developing relationships will certainly expedite your crypto learning journey.Â 

### ğŸ§± Build the FoundationÂ 

Unless itâ€™s your mother tongue, mastering any language requires you to put in the hard work of memorizing vocabulary and learning the grammar. Without knowing enough words, no matter how many English songs you listen to or how many English-speaking friends you make, you will never become fluent. If the structural rules of the language evade you, itâ€™s nearly impossible to make sense of all the words.Â 

Crypto is no different. As previously mentioned, at its foundation, crypto as a language also consists of vocabulary and grammar. Therefore, the same method one uses to acquire new words and study grammar can also be applied. For example, when encountering new vocabulary in conversations or articles, write them down and look up the definitions. If you want to investigate a sector, grasp the building block knowledge first to equip yourself with conceptual understanding so that you can navigate anything new thereafter. For example, in order to understand the DeFi sector, you must first learn what [ERC-20](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/erc20) tokens are, what Liquidity Pools are about, and why Automated Market Maker was invented. Then you can advance to researching automated lending and borrowing platforms, such as Aave and Compound, and start experimenting with investment strategies like Yearn and Alchemix.

### ğŸš€ â€œGo Abroadâ€

A popular piece of advice people give to learn a new language is to go abroad. It totally makes sense. Once you are in a country that speaks the language, you are forced to be present in that environment. It becomes much easier to make friends with native speakers. The key here is to create that immersive experience for yourself and find support when you need it.Â 

With the existence of the Internet and how everything in crypto is built, â€œgoing abroadâ€ has never been easier. For crypto as a language, going abroad means using whatever protocols or dApps you are learning, reading their whitepapers or articles on Mirror and Medium, following their Twitter accounts, and hopping into their Discord channels to meet other community members of the same product. If you want to understand what Aave v3 is all about, put some money in (*not financial advice*), and try out different functionalities. If you want to see what a DAO is about, join the DAO, talk to the people there, and start contributing.Â 

### ğŸ„ Have Fun!

Life is about the journey, not the destination. When learning a natural language, itâ€™s not just about becoming fluent. Itâ€™s about opening doors to new experiences. While learning a language, you get to learn about the culture and history surrounding that language. Equipped with the new language, you are able to travel around and converse with the local people.Â 

In the land of crypto, the possibilities are similarly endless. Itâ€™s not just about becoming a crypto native. After all, the crypto language is just a conduit. You are learning crypto because you feel a sense of attraction; you want to satisfy your curiosity, unlock new experiences, make some new friends, and find a community you belong to in the space.Â 

So, while some days it is about the grind, donâ€™t forget to enjoy yourself along the way. Take a pause and smell the flowers. Give yourself a pat on the back and feel proud of what you have done.Â 

## Closing Thoughts

The old proverb says, â€œall roads lead to Romeâ€. Everyone has their own unique ways of learning a new language and the paths they take to get into crypto. I want to stress that I am by no means a crypto native or a polyglot. I share my journey and thoughts on learning crypto as a new language in hopes that this can be somewhat helpful to those with a similar curiosity. Please reach out if you feel alone on this journey, as I did a few months ago, or just want to chat about crypto and get excited together.Â 

Last but not least, I want to thank everyone who has helped me and supported me on my journey so far ğŸ™. Without you, my experience would certainly not have been the same ğŸ«¶.

*Special thanks to [Brandon Mason](https://www.linkedin.com/in/brandon-mason-02b41b123/), [Andrew Hong](https://twitter.com/andrewhong5297), and [Chuxin Huang](https://twitter.com/chuxin_h) for editing, providing constructive feedback, and proofreading this piece!*
